content.description: Start on a rail and work along small crimps with balancy moves on one of the blankest of the wood sections.
content.protection: a bouldering pad or two have someone move it if you want to do the whole problem.
content.location: Woods wall, starts directly below pillar 8, look at the photo to identify the rail start. 15 feet left of Woodland Walk. Traverse your way right until you get to the 4th fence section from the 7th pillar.

content.description: Start on the two holds in the picture, do a few difficult moves up some small crimps, then the holds get really good and the problem is over. If its rained recently, look out for some gross holds at the top, the cracks can have water/mud in them... pretty gross stuff. Bring chalk.    Top out or just come down when you hit the limestone at the top.
content.location: On the woods wall, between pillar 7 and 8, below the 6th fence section, look for a big jutting out rock with lots of sloped, smooth concrete on top of it, as pictured in the photo.   (For description of how to find routes/ problems on this wall, take a look at the photos of Eden Park, then take a look at the "Woods Wall" or "West Wall")

content.description:
NOTE This area is in development and would love it if you added your routes to it! If your climb here often, please drop a route on the page so that we can all find and try it. Please use the "pillar" and "fence section" terminology for locating routes on this wall. 

  The Woods Wall is just an extension of the West Wall, as it collides with the woods. This means that all of it can be done on top rope. The large pockets back here can get dirtier than on the West Wall, so expect some grimy holds. There is one gem of a top rope at the buttress where the West Wall meets the Woods Wall. 

  FINDING ROUTES:

  Routes and problems on this wall and the West Wall are located by "pillars and "fence-sections".    Pillars are the large columns that are at the top of the wall, running along the fence, and fence-sections are the smaller, sections of the fence, identified by the metal parts that stick out to the very edge of the wall (pictured in the photo).
